title: How to Avoid Getting Jumped (10 Must-Know Tips for Personal Safety)

steps.title: Keep your valuable technology hidden and stop distractions.
steps.content: Keep your valuable technology hidden and stop distractions. Contrary to popular belief, being on your phone isn’t likely to deter attackers since it actually signals that you’re distracted and easy to attack. Likewise, avoid walking with headphones because you won’t be able to pay as close of attention to noises around you. [1] X Research source [2] X Expert Source Saul Jaeger, MS Police Captain, Mountain View Police Department Expert Interview. 21 February 2020.

steps.title: Pick clothes that will allow you to run away if you’re attacked.
steps.content: Pick clothes that will allow you to run away if you’re attacked. Avoid wearing expensive-looking clothes, showing off flashy accessories, or carrying designer bags. [3] X Research source To make yourself look like a less valuable target, wear gym clothes or worn-out clothes and carry a gym bag. [4] X Research source If you are carrying a valuable bag, hold your bag closer to your body instead of letting it dangle where someone can grab it.

steps.title: Avoid walking past groups of people at night.
steps.content: Avoid walking past groups of people at night. If you spot groups of people standing on the street or see someone staring at you, try to choose a different path. If you can’t take a different path home, cross the street or remain alert of whether those people are trying to approach you. [5] X Expert Source Saul Jaeger, MS Police Captain, Mountain View Police Department Expert Interview. 21 February 2020. [6] X Research source As you assess a potentially dangerous situation, practice the OODA Loop, a system of decision-making developed by military strategists. In the OODA loop, you continually observe, orient, decide, and act. [7] X Research source Observe your surroundings by listening and watching people around you. Orient yourself by comparing what you see to what you would normally expect from a safe situation. Decide whether the people you see pose a threat to you. Do they seem angry? Are they yelling or staring at you intently? Act by running away or calling for help.

steps.title: Move your feet with purpose and let your arms swing.
steps.content: Move your feet with purpose and let your arms swing. By walking dynamically and with confidence , you make yourself seem strong and difficult to harass. Attackers are more likely to pick you if you look like a weak target. [8] X Expert Source Saul Jaeger, MS Police Captain, Mountain View Police Department Expert Interview. 21 February 2020. [9] X Research source Look bigger and more confident by keeping your chin up, spine straight, and preventing your shoulders from hunching. Walk briskly to seem more athletic than other potential victims. Just don’t walk too fast, or you’ll draw attention to yourself.

steps.title: Avoid walking past bushes, doorways, or alleys.
steps.content: Avoid walking past bushes, doorways, or alleys. Walking on the sidewalk close to the curb allows you to avoid places where people might be hiding and waiting to ambush you. As you walk around building corners, take wide turns so you have more time to assess who is on the other side. If you can’t stay close to the curb, just make sure to avoid alleys, vacant lots, and wooded areas. [10] X Research source If you’re not able to stay on the sidewalk, walk against the flow of car traffic. That way, it’ll be harder for you to be pulled into a car by a thief or kidnapper.

steps.title: Don’t ask for directions, and don’t pull out a GPS or map.
steps.content: Don’t ask for directions, and don’t pull out a GPS or map. Attackers and muggers are more likely to prey on you if you seem unsure or lost. To act like you know the neighborhood and have a route home, take turns and cross the street without hesitating. Once you've reached a busy store, restaurant, or a well-lit place, you can ask for directions or use your phone to figure out where you are. On the other hand, if you know your route well and are concerned you’re being followed, pick a zig-zagging or less-intuitive path to get where you want to go. You’ll get the opportunity to lose the person following you and verify that you’re being stalked. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Just keep walking.
steps.content: Just keep walking. If you’re feeling unsure about someone approaching you, check in with your instincts regarding the situation. If you feel threatened in any way, walk right past the person and don’t break your stride. When you stop, you give a potential muggers or attacker the chance to distract you. [12] X Research source Potential attackers might ask for the time or for directions. Once you look down to check your watch or phone, you put yourself into a vulnerable position by taking your eyes off the potential mugger.

steps.title: Make lots of noise to alert people around you if you’re in danger.
steps.content: Make lots of noise to alert people around you if you’re in danger. If someone is following you in a public place, ask for help from passers-by. If your attacker confronts you, scream immediately. Resisting your attackers makes you a more difficult target, and noise might alert others to intervene. [13] X Research source For example, you could tell someone, “I’m afraid this person is following me. Can you help me?”

steps.title: Move somewhere with a crowd, lights, and security cameras.
steps.content: Move somewhere with a crowd, lights, and security cameras. If you think you’re in danger of getting jumped, go into a store, restaurant, or bank where you can find other people. If there’s a security guard who works at the establishment, you can let them know the situation or even ask them to walk you to your car. [14] X Research source

steps.title: Call 9-1-1 or your local emergency number.
steps.content: Call 9-1-1 or your local emergency number. Let them know if you’re being followed or feel threatened by someone. Try to give the police information on the suspicious person’s sex, race, age, hair and eye color as well as any other identifying features. [15] X Expert Source Saul Jaeger, MS Police Captain, Mountain View Police Department Expert Interview. 21 February 2020. [16] X Research source
